subject: Critical Thinking
title: What Is a Cognitive Bias?
description: A micro-lesson that makes What Is a Cognitive Bias? usable.

hook.text: Your brain makes 35,000 decisions a day. It shortcuts most of them. Some shortcuts go spectacularly wrong.

buildup.text: A cognitive bias is a systematic error in thinking â€” a predictable pattern where logic fails.

discovery.text: Kahneman and Tversky identified dozens in the 1970s, proving humans aren't the rational actors economists assumed.

twist.text: Biases aren't bugs â€” they're features. They evolved to make fast decisions when perfect ones are too slow.

climax.text: The problem: our Stone Age shortcuts now operate in a world of stocks, statistics, and social media.

punchline.text: Your brain is fast. That's the problem.

quiz.question: What are cognitive biases?
options: Systematic, predictable patterns of flawed reasoning
